The Nine Arch Bridge in Ella, Sri Lanka is a celebrated colonial-era railway viaduct also called the Bridge in the Sky. It was completed in 1921 and built entirely of stone, brick, and cement without steel reinforcement, a creative adaptation due to steel shortages during World War I. Wikipedia+1 The bridge spans about 91 m (300 ft) with nine elegant arches rising approximately 24 m (80 ft) above a lush jungle valley, set among tea plantations and misty hills. Lanka Pradeepa+1 It remains fully operational, carrying trains between Ella and Demodara stations, and is one of Sri Lanka‚Äôs most photographed attractions. Wikipedia Decorative nighttime lighting has been installed recently to let visitors appreciate the bridge after dark, enhancing tourism experiences. Train times passing the bridge - 6.30am, 9.30 am, 11.30 am, 3.30 pm, 4.30pm, 5.30pm

The Nine Arches Bridge, nestled in the scenic town of Ella in Sri Lanka, is a remarkable feat of engineering and a symbol of the island‚Äôs natural beauty and colonial past. Completed in 1921 during British rule, this iconic railway bridge spans 91 meters in height and stretches over 300 meters in length, arching gracefully across a lush, verdant valley. Its structure, characterized by nine large arches, is an awe-inspiring example of early 20th-century engineering, built using solid bricks and concrete without the use of steel. The bridge is strategically placed within a landscape of dense forests, rolling hills, and tea plantations, which offers visitors breathtaking panoramic views that have made it one of Sri Lanka's most photographed landmarks. As a key part of the railway line that connects Colombo to Badulla, the Nine Arches Bridge serves not only as a transportation route but also as a historical relic. The surrounding area, rich in biodiversity and serene beauty, has made it a prime destination for nature lovers, adventurers, and photographers. The bridge is often seen as a peaceful contrast to the hustle and bustle of urban life, offering a glimpse into Sri Lanka's colonial heritage. Tourists flock to this bridge to marvel at its intricate design and its ability to blend harmoniously with the surrounding natural environment. Whether visited during the misty mornings or the golden hours of sunset, the Nine Arches Bridge never fails to leave a lasting impression on those who encounter it. It remains an enduring symbol of Sri Lanka‚Äôs cultural and natural heritage, standing as a testament to the resilience of both the human spirit and the land it inhabits.

How many stone arch bridges (namely stone, without the use of reinforced concrete and other iron) do you know? Until I wrote this post, I didn‚Äôt really bother with this issue. It turns out that there are more than enough of them - STONE bridges in the world. True, there are not so many bridges made of stone, whose arched spans are at least 50 meters. Surely you have heard of the Juxigou Bridge in China, the Maidenhead Viaduct in England, the Solkan Bridge in Slovenia, the Heather Bridge in Iran, the Wiesen Viaduct in Switzerland, the Pont de Vieille Briude in France, etc. In total, I managed to count about six dozen wide-span bridges around the world. In reality, there are many times more stone bridges with narrow spans. But they are no less interesting, take the word of an old travel lover!!! But!!! How many of these STONE bridges are railway bridges? Even clever Wikipedia couldn‚Äôt answer this for me. During my trip to Sri Lanka, I was able to get acquainted with the local must see, which represents one of the best examples of colonial-era railway construction in Ceylon. Moreover, as they say, ‚Äúthree in one‚Äù: this is a BRIDGE, it is STONE and it is RAILWAY!!! I'm talking about the Nine Arches Bridge - the Bridge of Nine Arches. It is built across a swampy lowland near the village of Gotuwala between two railway stations - Ella and Demodara. This bridge is one of the favorite places for party-juice of insta-people: 9 out of 10 travel lovers will definitely not fail to visit this object to photograph the architectural ingenuity of the creators of the Bridge and the abundant tropical greenery on the nearby hillsides, and then post their smiling photo in the virtual world. For lovers of historical and engineering precision, the Nine Arches Bridge is a pain in the ass: only its dimensions are known from accurate information (length - 91.44 meters, width - 7.62 meters, height - 24.38 meters). AND THAT'S ALL!!! As for the time of its construction: according to one piece of information, work on the construction of the bridge began in 1912, according to another - a year later. If you believe some sources, the completion date of the mega-construction is 1921, others claim that it is 1923. At least a report entitled "Construction of a Concrete Railway Viaduct in Ceylon" was published by the Ceylon Engineering Association in 1923. Most guidebooks, as a rule, attribute the construction of the bridge to the local Ceylonese builder P.K. Appukhami in ‚Äúco-authorship‚Äù with some British engineers. In fact, there is a funny legend circulating regarding Comrade Appuhami and his role in the construction of the bridge. Evil tongues claim that he is not a builder. Allegedly in 1912, the popular drummer and performer of ‚Äúdevil dances‚Äù (yak·π£a n√¶·π≠uma) in Ceylon P.K. Appuhami was returning with another panty in the lift of that same Devil-Yaksha (Yak·π£ayƒÅ). At the station in Ohiya, he came across a certain son of Foggy Albion, who almost ‚Äúdid not move his horses‚Äù from fright, seeing the Yaksha appearance of our Phil Collins, Dave Grohl and Cozy Powell of the Sri Lankan ‚Äúspill‚Äù in ‚Äúone bottle‚Äù. Thank God, the Briton did not ‚Äúgrunt‚Äù and through him Appuhami ended things with the bridge builders and, as some not very trustworthy sources say, received the unofficial status of the chief engineer of the project. Whether this is true or not - only the drummer himself knows... The chief designer and manager of the ‚ÄúRailway Line to Ceylon‚Äù project was D.J. Vimalasurendra, supposedly another eminent Ceylonese engineer and inventor. The designer of the viaduct is said to be Harold Cuthbert Marwood of the Railway Construction Department of the Ceylon State Railway. And another epic Aboriginal tale associated with the personality of P.K. Appuhami: British engineers, led by the mentioned Mr. Marwood, have completely broken their heads, excuse the tautology - how to install 9 columns in the swampy quagmire of a valley? And then again - and like a jack-in-the-box, that same Appukhami!!! Ceylon drummer proposed an ingenious move, like ‚Äúcowards worth a ruble or forty,‚Äù: throwing huge boulders into the depression until they fill it. And on this ‚Äúpiled foundation‚Äù the columns were then installed!!! The huge bridge is located at an altitude of 945 meters above sea level, which is why its second name is ‚ÄúBridge in the Sky‚Äù. By the way, the uniqueness of this railway bridge beauty lies in the fact that it is entirely built from rocks, bricks and cement - without the use of steel or iron!!! And again, another story: when construction work began, the First World War broke out almost immediately. And, quite expectedly, the front needed iron... It seems that everything is clear: no material - no bridge!!! But the skillful Ceylonese peasants took and built the Bridge from bricks, cobblestones and cement. Without iron, therefore... How long can you do it skillfully? And now - from the realm of mysteries and mysticism... When I saw the Nine Arches Bridge, I was struck by the feeling of that same d√©j√† vu: I have already seen this building!!! Well, or something very, very similar!!! Of course: Istanbul's Bozdogan, Tarragona's "Devil's Bridge", Rome's Parco degli Acquedotti... And what do we get? Dear Sri Lankan bridge builders, I suppose, who had no idea about antiquity, simply erected a unique arched bridge in the style of ancient Roman viaducts without any iron load-bearing elements, using only stone, brick and cement??? A masterpiece of bridge construction based on technology a couple of millennia old??? Do you believe this yourself, my dear reader??? Go ahead. Surely you noticed the unique bricks from which the bridge was built. The surface of the bricks is not flat, but convex (external lining) or concave (internal lining). So: neither the then Ceylon nor the metropolis (that is, Britain) knew the technology for making such figured and, as it turned out, durable bricks. And you, like the author of these lines, will probably not find information about where this brick was made. But this is not ten, not a hundred, or even a thousand pieces of figured brick - it had to be made somewhere??? Next - the very same - and again I use this word - UNIQUE - concrete: eternal, which resembles antique, the secret of which scientists have not yet unraveled (this concrete only becomes stronger over time, unlike modern concrete). More riddles? Yes, easily - I have them!!! Have you noticed the ‚Äúsmoky‚Äù appearance of the structure? It was so blackened already about 80 years ago - look at the photo from the middle of the last century!!! But how and why did ‚ÄúBridge to Heaven‚Äù become so terribly ‚Äúsmoky‚Äù in such a short period of time??? One more thing: after the discovery of photography in 1822 by the French inventor Joseph Nic√©phore Niepce, the topic of capturing everything and everyone quickly spread throughout the world. And the British, with their usual scrupulousness, began to photograph those same ‚Äúeverything and everything,‚Äù especially focusing on some significant events (including in the dominions and colonies). So - it turned out to be impossible to find ANY photographs of the construction of this grandiose facility for Ceylon!!! I don‚Äôt want to seem suspicious, but don‚Äôt you think that the Nine Arches Bridge was built, after all, not on the officially announced dates (the beginning of the 20th century) and not by British-Lankan builders, as the official history says??? This, I am not afraid of this word, artifact in its mystery is very reminiscent of the carved columns of the temple in the Indian city of Shravanabelagola, the Inca polygonal masonry in Peruvian Ollantaytambo, the dolmens of the Western Caucasus, stone balls at the mouth of the Costa Rican Diquis River, the Newgrange mound in Ireland, the White Pyramid in Chinese province of Shaanxi, Skara Brae complex on the shores of the Scottish Bay of Skyll etc. That is, those very objects whose origin modern science is unable to explain... As a version: for the railway ‚ÄúBridge to the Sky‚Äù in Sri Lanka, they simply took and adapted an already existing ANTIQUE VIADUCT!!! I answer the question in the air - why was the construction of the bridge attributed to the Sri Lankans (plus the ‚Äúco-authors‚Äù, the British)? When there is no explanation for how an ancient Roman viaduct appeared on an island in the Indian Ocean, it occurred to someone ‚Äúwise‚Äù to simply invent and fit the inexplicable fact described above into the official version. By the way, the Bridge of Nine Arches has NEVER been restored - it has retained its original charm and is still functioning. Isn't this a miracle??? Or just another mystery of an ancient civilization (by the way, maybe even an alien one). Highly recommend!!!

Eighteen of us, travelling together with Flamingo Tours, visited the Nine Arch bridge on 10th September 2023.  After visiting Demodera Railway Station, we hired tuk-tuks up to the bridge site - about five kilometres as the approach is not motorable by car. This railway bridge, constructed in 1921, entirely of stone bricks and cement, lies between Ella and Demodera railway stations.  It joins two hills along the rail line and is 80 - 100 feet high and 300 feet long. The bridge itself, bathed in morning sunlight, was a breathtaking sight at both ends.  We walked along the rail line, atop the bridge to the far side and back.  On either side of the bridge are little kiosks that sell king coconuts and other fruits. We were amongst a large crowd of tourists awaiting the arrival of the train.  Seeing the approaching train on this concave shaped nine arch bridge was certainly a memorable and a wonderful sight.  The train came slowly, allowing the visitors to capture photos of it on the concave bridge, before disappearing into the tunnel beyond.

So please do your homework (prior to arriving near the bridge to ensure you don't get taken for a ride, literally!)

We took a TukTuk from Ella as far as we could go on the dirt track and then walked down some steep steps down to the track A lovely walk along the railway to the bridge We timed it to see the evening train go by What a wonderful experience

Amazing bridge considering when it was built! Access is via the railway line and you  are able to walk across the bridge...watch out for trains! Great photo opportunities, some crazy people sitting on the bridge and even trying to stand on the edge.......long drop down! At the end of the day it's a bridge which a train travels over. Many tourists walking along the lines and standing or sitting on the edge of the bridge taking selfies. I believe Nine Arch is the most beautiful bridge in Sri Lanka. It's a great place for photos as it gives some amazing views!

Nice but not sure if it is worth waiting over an hour to see the train come by. If you are lucky enough to to be there close to the train time it would be perfect. It is seriously beautiful

Yes super touristic but with an amazing scenery! Make sure to follow the djungel path (its like a 30 min walk so you dont need a tuktuk) to experience the rich flora of sri lanka. We went around 5 and watched the sunset from there, which put the scwnery into an amazing light.

Sky bridge  s oldest name for nine arche bridge, due to railway track goes through nine arches ( bridge in the sky ) . A scenic place and enjoyable to pass through! We came straight from Little Adam‚Äôs Peak so had a lovely hike from the hills above which gave us great views of the Bridge. We walked there- both the long and the short way. It is really worth it. Chill, have a King Coconut, a mango or nothing as you discover the bridge. Do the train all the way to Badulla or just to the teafactory 6 km from Ella. Then you'll see it in another perspective as well.
Well worth a trip to watch the train go over the bridge followed by a walk over the bridge and through the tunnel. Great photo opportunities.

To round off our train adventure starting off at The Fort, Colombo stopping off at Kandy and Ella, We took a trip to the nine arch bridge organised by our homestay owner. Nice place to visit and take some pictures. Check the train timetable to catch the train! Suggest to walk there from Caf√© Eden (only like 10mins).

In middle of nowhere there is this iconic bridge for Sri Lankan people. Architectural design is not much, but combined with the nature and passing trains, it is a place to be seen.

We travelled to the Nine Arch Bridge via the lesser known second entrance point. (Further up the road) You can view the bridge from the track down to the rail line, then walk to the bridge along the line. We timed the trip to coincide with a train travelling over the bridge as well.

Depends where you hail from I guess.  We spend a lot of time walking in Derbyshire and the Monsal Head viaduct is better.  Go up into Yorkshire and the Settle/Carlisle viaduct is astounding.  Knocks this one out of the park.  It‚Äôs ok but a bit meh for us.

This bridge is fantastic to see and walk across. It is only a short hike out of Ella and a must see venue. The walk down to nine arches bridge is not well sign posted and people tend to find out about it by word of mouth or from a tour guide. The walk down to the bridge i so well worth it. the view of the bridge and from the bridge are magnificent. If you time things well you can walk along the tracks back into Ella or just enjoy walking along the bridge and through the tunnel. We walked along the railway track & visited the 9 Arch Bridge. One has to appreciate the engineering that was used to build such a spectacular bridge. Luckily a trained passed by affording us with the opportunity to take great pics. Adam's Peak is just over the bridge too.

My first visit to Nine Arch Bridge was way back in 1988 as a teenager and i've been there many times over since then. Nice and impressive bridge in the jungle near Ella were tourist flock to see a train pass the bridge. The route we took was a bit difficult for a small child but enjoyed walking over the tracks after we also got our shot of the train passing the bridge. Nice to waste some time.
Try to get there early for photos as many tourists also go there all day. Long train track walk but worth the effort.

Courtesy of Instagram it's a must do, we went early at like 6.30ish am. All the locals said go later but we prefer to dodge the crowds. It's a pretty easy walk 10-20 minutes pending where you come from, the way we went got a little off road towards the end of the trail. Nine Arch Bridge is an awesome place to visit. It is a bridge in Nine Arches and looks damn beautiful.

One of the most visited places in Ella, the nine arc bridge is very Picturesque and surely the best attraction to visit. Probably one of the most photographed landmarks in Ella, the 9-arches bridge is a piece of beautiful architecture built by the British. I wish Lonely Planet has covered this more thoroughly.  There are not enough signs to show you how to reach this point and definitely not enough coverage about how steep and slippery the slope could be on the way to the bridge.  Hope whoever reading this will find the following tips helpful: 1) If you take the entrance near 98 Acres, the entrance has a mini colorful Hindu shrine and a coconut stand. Follow the signs and walk uphill until you reach a fork with no sign in the middle of the hill, take the left fork that will bring you through a muddy path and keeps walking for another five min or so before you can see the bridge below you on the far left.  I was told there are other ways to get there but this path brings you to the classic instagram shot of the bridge when the train hits. 2) If you choose to take this path, then beware of a very slippery muddy slope. It was drizzling when we were in the middle of walking toward the nine arch bridge. Both my partner and I were in sneakers and we were slipping and almost fell on a few occasions when we tried to climb down the slope.  Many people also found it challenging towards the end. I am a 5 feet 2 Asian who rarely exercised. I managed to get down in one piece using an umbrella as a hiking stick and towards the end I had to rely on my hand on the ground to keep myself from slipping a few times.  I also had help from my partner and a few kind tourists.  I would feel a lot safer with trekking shoes and a hiking stick, and I would not recommend visiting this place if it is raining. 3) Try to ask your hotel for the train schedule. The experience was so much more fun with the train passing by with passengers waving and cheering. A few brave tourists sat on the bridge when the train passed by.  It took me about 50 minutes to walk from 98 Acres resort to the bridge.  On the day I went, which was a Sunday, I was told trains would pass through the bridge around 9:20am, 1:45pm and 3:15pm.

The road to Nine Arc Bridge was a really adventure since the heavy rain flushed al signs of road away. But with great TukTuk-drivers we arrived safely and happy. It was really nice to see this marvelous bridge in close. So, it was worth al effort.
It was raining on the day I visited, so not overcrowded. Unfortunately, the train was running late on the day, would be  good to plan so could see the train going over the bridges
First of the to be done in your life place in sri Lanka Go early morning to be alone Or check the train schedule for make an amazing picture

Its basically a bridge that you can see the likes of on a larger scale in many areas of the U.K. but if your a gap year student type that wants to put it on you IG please enjoy.
It's a nice bridge and nice setting but not something remarkable in comparison to some of the nearby settings like little Adams peak or Ella rock.

One of the main attraction points of Ella. Worth seeing definitely. This is a beauty! One impressive bridge. Do read its story from Google before heading then it will excite you more. For this also, little trek is there & morning time according to the train time you can go there & have amazing memories. Not to miss while in Sri Lanka!

The nine arch bridge was built in the colonial era by british with the aid of sri lankan labour force,The location has now become a tourist/local must see place in ella.The bridge can be reach in 02 ways mainly,ella/passara road and also via bandarawela/badulla road,better to visit when there is a train on its way where you can take beautiful pictures with the running train. if you visit between 12 noon to 3.30 pm to the top of the bridge you have a good possibility to catch 1 out of 3 trains which is schdule to run over.the bridge view is free of charge and do not give any money to unwanted people.The local authoroty has place sri lankan police  in case you have any question they will help you
Great place for nice photos. Train schedule is not fixed. Have good shoes. Muddy way down. Be careful.

Beautiful but crowded, plenty of people taking pictures. The view is amazing though, so recommend visiting just be ready for a lot of other people having the same idea. Worth walking down to the bridge and around a bit - the path through the forest is a great walk and saves you walking through the polluted main street.

We didn't have much time in Ella unfortunately, but I'm glad we did the short hike down to the 9 Arch Bridge, despite the rainy weather. We went to see this famous bridge half an hour be4 train passed. We rented a tuk tuk becoz we were tired to walk up and down. A rare sunny and dry start so headed to the bridge. Not too busy at 8.30am. Waited for the train and got some good photos. Sweet doggies to cuddle while waiting for the blue train.

I went there through the village not the train tracks. It has been raining in the evenings so the route was so muddy and slippery so won't recommend that route there then view was good however I ended up paying $1000 to come back to Ella üôÑüôÉ

We had a bit of difficulty climbing down the stairs.Once that was done,it was great fun to walk on the railway track.A reasonable restaurant at the site.The bridge is .beautiful and lovely spot for taking pictures.The high point was whena train passed by,people cheering from the train and us spectators taking pictures.nice place!
Amazing views walking along the track waiting for the blue train. Nice hike up to the area from the bottom Of little Adams peak...
I went to see nine arche's bridge 3 weeks back. I recommend this place to all the travelers around the world.
Worth the walk. Can get slippery! Get down there. Sit on the edge. Do the tunnel. Drink coconuts. Take a 100 photos and enjoy!

Not a long walk but we‚Äôd had a little rain so grippy shoes were a benefit. there are some parts that were a bit of a struggle going down with some bigs steps in the track and using your hands to steady yourself either side was necessary so ended up a bit grubby from wiping muddy fingers on my shorts! Worth it though. We were lucky as hadn‚Äôt researched what time the train passed through, but after speaking to some other people beginning to gather we found out a train was due within thirty minutes. Just enough time for a snack and drink at the reasonably priced cafe across the bridge. We got some great photos- the colour of the train looks fantastic against the lush green backdrop and the impressive brick bridge structure.

Absolutely gorgeous bridge and a highlight of Ella. It's completely free and beautiful, so make sure you do it! It's an easy and cheap tuk tuk ride (about 200 Sri Lankan Rupees) or you can walk it (less than 2 miles, but not a great path to walk on, you walk on the road)
Good location. Maybe there should be a way to bring the vehicle all the way near. Passing train on the bridge looks amazing.

This is one of the best places to visit in Ella after little Adam's peak. How to reach - There are two ways to reach here. One is the longer, flat road which is usually taken by tuk tuks. If you do not want to hike then choose this road. The tuk tuk might take 800-1000 LKR to bring you here and back. Another route is the one followed by people on foot or who like to hike. The hike is moderate. You need to hike down the hill on your way to the bridge and then go up on your way back. There are no stairs for most part of the hike and you will have to climb up and down rocks so dress appropriately. When to go - If possible, time your visit such that you can see a train passing through the bridge. It's not a big deal, but if you have the time and you are already visiting the bridge, then why not? You can ask the locals and they will be able to help you with the exact time of train crossing through the bridge. Trains are almost always on time. How much time to spend - You can easily spend an hour here taking pictures of and with the bridge and the tunnel. If you have time to kill you can also take a stroll through the tracks. My wife, our grandson Ryan and I, left our car at Ella Railway Station on 23rd July 2019 and hired a tuk-tuk to see the Nine Arch Bridge.  The road to the bridge is in bad state of disrepair and narrow with sharp curves.  Although we hired a tuk-tuk, one can walk from the Ella station, along the railway line, to the Nine Arch Bridge, a distance of about 3 kilometers. There are only a few trains plying this route.  The tuk-tuk driver hurried along to be in time to show us the train crossing over the bridge.  The bridge, as the name suggests, is built over nine arches atop tall walls, and runs over the 100 ft deep ravine.  It is called the "sky bridge" emphasising the depth of the ravine.  On that beautiful sunny morning, it was a wonderful sight to observe the train moving over this unique bridge. The train moved slowly over the bridge allowing me to capture a few attractive photographs. The bridge had been commissioned in 1921, built during the British Rule.  The world war I broke out while it was being built.  The consignment of steel earmarked for the bridge was diverted to the army for projects associated with the war.  If steel were available, the bridge could have been built with only two or three spans across the ravine.  Since there was no steel available, the engineers incorporated eight shorter spans supporting the bridge over these nine convex arches.  Blocks of stone joined together with cement were the sole construction materials used in its construction. On its journey from Ella to Demodera the railway line passes through a 60 metre long tunnel about 75 metres after the arch bridge.  Don‚Äôt miss out on taking a photo with you at the entrance to the tunnel!  There were many excited tourists watching the train moving along!!
